Fain charged by you in your last Occi„
dent with inconsistency.

For myself, I am regardless of the said such an accusation, being
full satisfied, being with the Purity and Rectitude of my
Intentions, and as my position at present, with the Congre„
gation Beth Elohim of Charleston in which among whom I have the honor to teach,
would render it improper and undignified to enter into a full
exposition of my principles, so long after my election.

I must therefore respectfully request, that you will suspend
your Opinion in relation to my Course, until the period
shall arrive, when it may become necessary, that I should
appear before my Brethern under my own name in
defence of Truth, Justice, and the Holy Word of God.

Sincerity and Candor, are certainly Virtues which we great„
ly admire; but we should be careful, how we pass sentence,
before we are full possessed of facts and circumstances con„
nected with the subject upon which we are about to decide.

For your satisfaction, however, I would state, that my
views were fully and plainly expressed to those members
of the Congregation who presented themselves for that purpose,
previous to my election and, nevertheless, I was elected contrary to my expectations,
by an almost unanimous Vote—I believe only one In„
dividual having voted against me in the negative, who has
since become one of my warmest friends and supporters

While I regard my humble acquiescence to the requi„
sitions of the Circular, of the Congregation Beth Elohim
of Charleston, as admissible according to the letter of
strict Judaism, I have never hesitated on all occasions, after the
I have earliest period of my arrival „to oppose
any thing that encroached upon the principles
of ancient Judaism, as that might have the ten„
dency to wound the feelings of the pious and con„
scientious Israelite, whose sincere attachments and
affections claim our highest Respect and Attention.

That the Almighty God blessed be He, may enable His
humble servant, and the most trying circumstances
to effect some little good among his people,
in his is the most fervent and ardent Prayer.

Note by the Editor It is indeed painful in the extreme for one like
us to be called upon to insert communications as in the last number
of our magazine wherein the merits of opposite opinions are
discussed, and upon which we are in a measure called upon
to pass our opinion, for to say nothing when grave measures
of principle are at stake would at once show that we are unworthy to occupy the editorial supervision of a Jewish periodical the ?

of which it is to speak out boldly on all matters affecting Judaisia. We
were called upon to print a piece depracatory of some remarks about
Mr Poznanski which he had inserted, and which had appeared solely because
Mr P. stood as the representative of certain ideas against which we have
always protested and against which we have preached & written for a
number of years. We had therefor no injustice to that gentleman to let
an intelligent correspondent who is himself a liberal altho' ? writer
disturb Mr P. in his retirement, especially since we are assured that
he has still a strong party devoted to him and his principles. At the
same time another friend forwarded to us the a commendation of the
course of Mr P.'s successor in office, a gentleman highly praised for his
learning and zeal, and the powerful and disintersted efforts he is making
to bring his flock back to a proper mode of thinking on religious matters.
We are perfectly willing to let the Occident speak on behalf of such
laudable efforts, and we wish with all our heart that they may be
successful to the fullest extent. But can any one assert that we
should not at the same time protest against the propriety of any
gentleman's taking office where he is brought forward as the defender
of opinions which we must condemn? Can it be asked of us that
we should by our silence endorse a course of proceeding which
we would never have adopted? We leave it to Dr Eckman himself
and our valued friends who find fault with our notice of last month,
whether we could have acted otherwise. We know full well that
Dr. E's position is a faithful one in the extreme; to stand as the
mediator between two opinions and endeavour honestly to execute?
there, is a task which the greatest minds may fail under; we
admire his courage to defy so powerful an opponent as Mr Poznanski
who both from his connexions & talents is an opponent of no one ?;

but all this does not reach our first objection, which is that the Dr.
Eckman should have hesitated before he assured ? in full
of danger & difficulties. We should deeply regret that our remarks
should have thrown in his way the least obstacle, as have the
best to diminish his usefulness. But if so it was entirely una
voidable; we belong to no school of of reformers, we know of no one here
living in Europe whose footsteps we could safely follow; and let our
teachers in this country place themselves on the platform of
Scripture & tradition, and they may depend on our support little
as this is just now, and nothing that we can affect shall be left
undone to assist them in their labours.

We are perfectly aware that Dr. E. cannot of his own accord
revive? the organ or restore religion in Charleston; and that all he
can do in his present position is to bring matters in train? for a future
restoration to the ancient standard. But we only ask of him that
he should declare against all that has been done, openly
and unequivocally; let there be no reservation of mind, nothing
be left for any doubt, and then can we speak as approvingly on our
personal friends so now of the Reverend Doctor. Let us again repeat
that we attack no man's motives; but surely we have an undoubted
right to say that these men of Israel who feel a deep interest in
the maintenance of a uniformity in religion have a claim on
all who profess to teach to speak without disguise and to
labour without fear, without regarding whom their word may
indite?. Let us beware of that most dangeris enemy to truth
flattery; let our teachers also guard against self-deception, and
let the people see that they support these most who show the worst consistency; and all will be well. We have for our fault no wrongs
to revenge against any of our public men in the country, and
what we say of them is the simple expression? of our honest contribution
We know well enough that this does not bring us many friends; but it
at least proves that we speak what we believe the truth.

Now as respects Dr. E. we are pleased to record that his views were known
before his election; and let us therefore hope that all who now differ from him
